title: Dionysos und die griechische Tragödie. Tübingen: Classica Monacensia 1. An exhaustive account of the mentions of Dionysos in tragedy
Liber Pater. Paris. A comprehensive account of the Roman god who was identified with Dionysos
Ancient Mystery Cult
The best existing treatment of its theme
Dionysian Imagery in Archaic Greek Art
A cautious and well-illustrated treatment. What survives is almost entirely vase-painting
Dionysian Imagery in Fifth-Century Athens
A cautious and well-illustrated treatment. What survives is almost entirely vase-painting
The Masks of Dionysos. Ithaca and London: Cornell University Press. A collection of essays by various scholars on various aspects of the god, with an excellent bibliography
Il Vino dell’ Anima. Storia del culto di Dioniso a Corinto, Sicione, Trezene. Rome: Il Calamo. An example of what can be extracted from focusing on a single region of Greece
Dionysos Slain (translation of Dionysos mis à mort, Paris 1977
Contains a structuralist account of the political significance of the myth of the killing of Dionysos

note: Contains the Greek text and influential Introduction and Commentary.
title: Euripides Bacchae

container-title: Harvard Studies in Classical Philology. 82.121–60. The best historical account of maenadism, based largely on inscriptions
title: Greek Maenadism from Olympia to Messalina’

note: Largely on the relation of individual to group in Dionysiac cult.
title: Changing Dionysiac Identities’
Self-Definition in the Graeco-Roman World
Loss of Self, Suffering, Violence: the Modern View of Dionysus from Nietzsche to Girard’, Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 88.205–40. A critical overview of modern accounts of Dionysos

Dionysos nella Grecia arcaica. Pisa and Rome: Istituti Editoriali e Poligrafici Internazionali. An account of Dionysos, and his retinue, in archaic painting that (in contrast to Carpenter) introduces anthropological and historical perspectives
Choisir Dionysos. Les Associations Dionysiaques ou la face cachée du Dionysisme
An indispensable collection and discussion of the numerous inscriptions relating to Dionysiac associations

note: A Jungian account, with an enormous range of material.
title: Dionysos. Archetypal Image of Indestructible Life

note: Dionysos as god of mystery-cult is brought to bear on interpreting Aristophanes’ Frogs.
title: Initiating Dionysos
A very extensive list of visual images of Dionysos
Interpretation and Dionysos. The Hague: Mouton. A lucid account of modern interpretations of Dionysos

note: Collects the large number of tombs of the imperial period sculpted with reliefs on Dionysiac themes.
title: Die Dionysische Sarkophage
Die Geburt der Tragödie aus dem Geist der Musik
Contains a seminal account of the Dionysiac

note: Other works contain much about Dionysos, for example his two-volume history of Greek religion (Geschichte der griechischen Religion).
title: The Dionysiac Mysteries of the Hellenistic and Roman Age. Lund. Somewhat out of date, but one of the very few works of Nilsson to have been translated into English
Dionysus. Myth and cult (translated from the German of 1933). Indiana University Press. An ahistorical vision of Dionysos as the embodiment of epiphany and contradiction
Polytheism and Society at Athens
Contains a good recent account of the Dionysiac festivals at Athens

note: Rohde believed that Dionysos arrived in Greece from Thrace, but has now been contradicted by the discovery of Bronze Age texts.
title: The Cult of Souls and Belief in Immortality among the Ancient Greeks (translation from the German
Contains an influential account of Dionysiac cult as a cult of souls

container-title: Introduction, Greek text, Translation and Commentary. Adduces politics and mystery-cult
title: Euripides Bacchae. Aris and Phillips
Ter Unis. Isis, Dionysos, Hermes: Three Studies in Henotheism
Illuminates Euripides’ Bacchae from a historical perspective that includes general discussion of the introduction of new gods into Athens

container-title: Also cited are the following Bérard
title: Several of the works in the Further Reading section are cited in the text
Anodoi
Trance and the Transformation of the Actor in Japanese Noh and Balinese Masked Dance-Drama
The Greeks and the Irrational
The Acts of the Apostles. A Commentary
Painter and Poet in Ancient Greece
Music and Trance
